text: Hugh Burdett Money-Coutts, 6th Baron LatymerNPG details (13 August 1876 – 23 November 1949) was an English peer. He inherited the title Baron Latymer from his father, Francis Money-Coutts, 5th Baron Latymer.thePeerage.com Money- Coutts was educated at Radley College and New College, Oxford. After university he joined the Royal Navy Volunteer Reserve.London Gazette 22 March 2004 In 1900 he married Hester Frances, the 4th daughter of Major-General John Cecil Russell, CVO:[http://www.cracroftspeerage.co.uk/online/content/latymer1431.htm Cracrofts they had three sons and one daughter.Geneanet He came within 50 votes of winning the seat of Petersfield for the Liberals in the 1906 United Kingdom general election. In 1908 he moved to Stoodleigh in Devon.Stoodleigh Court In 1910 he left the Liberals to join the Conservatives. His Times obituary states that from this time he was an "effective controversialist" on the subject of Tariff Reform.'Lord Latymer' The Times (London, England), Friday, November 25, 1949, Issue 51548, p.7. During the World War One he served as an officer in the Royal North Devon Yeomanry.London Gazette 25 August 1914 He wrote 'The Broads' in 1919;World Cat 'Chances and Changes' in 1931; and 'Stalking in Scotland and New Zealand' in 1935.National Library of New Zealand == References == Category:1876 births Category:1949 deaths Category:British Army personnel of World War I Category:People educated at Radley College Category:Alumni of New College, Oxford Category:20th-century Royal Navy personnel Category:Barons Latimer
title: Hugh Burdett Money-Coutts, 6th Baron Latymer
